abstract.p: Q & A column compares environmental impact of using garbage disposal with throwing organic waste into trash; drawing (S)

block.p: Q. Which does less harm to the environment: putting kitchen waste, like unusable food, into a garbage disposal or into the trash, which ends up in a landfill?

A. Assuming the ground organic materials end up in a sewage plant, where they can go through biological treatment, it is better to send them through a garbage disposal into the drain, in the opinion of Dr. Allen Hershkowitz, senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Q. Which does less harm to the environment: putting kitchen waste, like unusable food, into a garbage disposal or into the trash, which ends up in a landfill?

A. Assuming the ground organic materials end up in a sewage plant, where they can go through biological treatment, it is better to send them through a garbage disposal into the drain, in the opinion of Dr. Allen Hershkowitz, senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council.
''At a landfill, these materials wind up causing methane gas emissions and contributing to the breakdown of other cellulose materials, which release greenhouse gases,'' Dr. Hershkowitz said.

He noted that the methane-producing microorganisms called methanogens that are associated with organic garbage act on other materials in a landfill so that they also release hazardous air emissions, some of them carcinogenic.
''Basically you do not want wet organic material in a landfill,'' Dr. Hershkowitz said. ''Landfills should be kept dry. You do not want landfills to break down. They are supposed to be entombed.''

Noxious landfill gases are sometimes captured for use as fuel, but there is also the potential problem of toxic liquid runoff, even if the landfill has a liner. A good alternative to either the drain or the dump is composting organic waste if possible, Dr. Hershkowitz said. ''That will not add load to sewage treatment plants,'' he said.
